column4: are you still around?  removing all those kernels broke the wireless on my wife's dell mini, that is why I'm not allowed to touch her computer

I noticed while removing kernels it kept saying stuff like wl.ko was active in this kernel, something about dkms to install module or something like that.  I'm assuming this is a known issue with the broadcom drivers for the wireless of this thing??
anyone know about the dell inspiron 10 that had ubuntu pre-installed 10.04?  removing old kernels seems to have broken the wireless connection
Thats not a bug, because the module names are the same between kernels.
ok, but for some reason the wireless is not loaded, or working
I ran 'ifconfig -a' and it only showed eth0 and lo, nothing for wireless
Still, the names are the same, and the messages just told you, that there were modules built using dkms.
ok, what should be my next step, google pulls up a lot of stuff that is irrelevant
Uninstall the old kernels you want to be uninstalled.
beaks, ok, I did that, I left all but the last 3 or 4
Now you should have much more space avail, dont you?
yes, space is great, I think it was something like 64% free for the inodes.
Then everything is ok :)
however, it doesn't connect to the web now, I'm on my laptop
Then you removed more than you should.
bekks; I don't think I did, I left the latest few kernels I think .37 .38 .39 and .40  however I'm not sure how to see what kernel it is booting off
uname -a tells you which kernel is currently active
ok, but how do I select what kernel to boot?
in the grub menu
beaks grub menu doesn't show on this, ubuntu was pre-installed, and I haven't messed with it hardly at all.
ˆˆˆ
it booted off 2.6.32-41  so I'm thinking I'm going to boot off the old kernel to see if that works, once I figure out how.
